questions.question: Salivary amylase is inactivated by which of the following?
questions.explanation: Salivary amylase is inactivated by the low pH of the stomach. It is rapidly denatured at pH 4.(gastric pH is 1 to 3.5).Salivary amylase is activated by chloride.○Salivary amylase (Ptyalin):• Digests starch: cleaves internal ° -1,4-glycosidic bonds in starch•Optimum pH: 7• Denatured at pH 4Since a large portion of a meal often remains unmixed for a considerable length of time in thestomach, the salivary enzyme may account for the digestion of as much as 75% of the starchpresent before it is denatured by gastric acid.Note: Even in the absence of salivary amylase, there is no defect in carbohydrate digestionbecause pancreatic amylase is sufficient to digest all of the ingested starch.

questions.question: Which of the following gland secretes lingual lipase?
questions.explanation: Lingual lipase is secreted by von Ebner's gland.von Ebner's gland is a serous salivary gland situated around circumvallate and foliate papillae infront of the terminal sulcus.Lingual lipase hydrolyse dietary lipid. The optimal pH is 3-6. Unlike pancreatic lipase, it is notinhibited by bile salts, medium-chain FA, and lecithin. Hence, it remains active through thestomach and into the intestine.566

questions.question: Which of the following fluids have the highest daily secretion of potassium?
questions.explanation: The highest daily secretion of K+ is into the saliva.In the process of formation of saliva, Na+ and Cl- are reabsorbed from the saliva, and K+ andHCO3 are secreted into the saliva.Note: The highest concentration of K+ is in the rectal fluid.

questions.question: The secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland causing a patient to salivate, pass through whichof the following ganglions?
questions.explanation: The secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland pass through the Otic ganglion.Salivary secretion is almost entirely controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system. Volume ismainly mediated by parasympathetic stimulation while the composition of saliva (increasedproteinaceous content) is slightly modified by sympathetic input.The parasympathetic preganglionic fibers are delivered by the glossopharyngeal and facial nervesto otic and submandibular ganglion respectively.Regulation of salivary secretion by the parasympathetic nervous system:Regulation of salivary secretionby the parasympathetic nervous systemConditioned reflexesSmellTastePressureNauseaGlossopharyngealnerveSuperior and inferiorsalivatory nucleiof the medullaFacialnerveFatigueSleepFearDehydrationOticganglionSubmandibularganglionParotidglandOMARROWSubmandibular andsublingual gland

questions.question: Rennin is present in
questions.explanation: Rennin is present in the gastric juice. It is also called chymosin.It is a protein-digesting enzyme (endopeptidase) found in the stomach of newborn cows. Ittransforms (curdles) caseinogen into insoluble casein.In humans and in some animals that lack rennin, milk is coagulated by the action of pepsin.567Note: Renin is produced by juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney, which hydrolyzes angiotensinogento angiotensin I.

questions.question: A patient presents with anemia and achlorhydria. After evaluation, pernicious anemia isdiagnosed. Damage to which of the following cells is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Pernicious anemia develops due to autoimmune damage to the parietal cells in gastric glands.The parietal cells secrete both HCl and intrinsic factor. Therefore, when the parietal cells aredestroyed, both achlorhydria, as well as pernicious anemia, develop.Pernicious anemia occurs due to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle, which is importantfor the absorption of vitamin B12.

questions.question: Which of the following is secreted by the Goblet cells?
questions.explanation: Goblet cells secrete mucus. These cells are located on the surface of the crypts of Lieberkuhnand the villi of the small intestine.Cells present in the crypts of Lieberkuhn:Goblet cells (similar to surface cells of the stomach) - secrete mucus that acts as a lubricant andprotects the intestinal surface••Epithelial cells - secrete succus entericus (intestinal secretion)-Paneth cells secrete lysozymes and defensins (antibacterial substances)

questions.question: In the stomach, H+ ions are secreted in exchange for which of the following ions?
questions.explanation: H+ ions are secreted into the lumen of the stomach in exchange for K+ by the H+-K+ pump (H+,K+-ATPase).Mechanism of HCl formation:•• In the parietal cells, CO2 and H2O are converted to H+ and HCO3-, catalyzed by carbonicanhydrase.• H+ is secreted into the lumen of the stomach by the H+-K+ pump in exchange for K+.• HCO3- moves out of the cell into the bloodstream in exchange for Cl- (Cl-HCO3-exchange).This Cl- moves into the lumen of the stomach.•H+ and Cl combine to form HCl.568BloodMechanism of HCI secretionGastric parietal cellCO2CO2CO2+H2OMARH2CO3CarbonicanhydraseHCO3CICrLumenH+H+ H+H+HCO3- + H+K+K+1 ADPHCI1 ATPOMARROWCrcr crAs HCO3- is added to the venous blood, the pH of the blood increases. This is called alkalinetide. Eventually, this HCO3- will be secreted in the pancreatic secretions to neutralize H+ in thesmall intestine.Proton pump inhibitors inhibit H+-K+ pump.

questions.question: A patient diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease is found to have excess gastricsecretion. All of the following are likely to increase the secretion, except:
questions.explanation: Gastric secretion is not increased by HCl. HCl decreases gastric secretion via a negative feedbackmechanism.Low pH due to HCl in the stomach inhibits gastrin secretion, which in turn, inhibits H+ secretion.Hence, the presence of HCl inhibits gastric secretion.Stimuli that increase acid and gastrin secretion:• Distension of stomach• Peptides• Calcium• Alcohol and caffeine• Increased vagal dischargeStimuli that decrease acid and gastrin secretion:• Gastric acid• Secretin family - secretin, glucagon, VIP, GIP• Somatostatin• CCK, Calcitonin• PGE2569

questions.question: A patient with recurrent abdominal pain is found to have multiple duodenal ulcers. After adetailed evaluation, he is diagnosed with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Stimulation of which ofthe following can inhibit gastric secretion in this patient?558
questions.explanation: Gastric secretion is inhibited by somatostatin.It inhibits gastric secretion via both direct and indirect pathways:• Direct pathway - somatostatin acts directly on the acid-producing parietal cells by binding toreceptors on parietal cells that are coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gi protein. This inhibitsadenylyl cyclase, and cAMP levels are reduced. In this way, somatostatin antagonizes thestimulatory effect of histamine on H+ secretion.•Indirect pathway - somatostatin inhibits the release of histamine and gastrin and thusdecreasing H+ secretion indirectly.Factors regulating H* secretionVagusG cellsECL cellsD cellsAchAtropineM3receptorGastrinHistamine Somatostatin ProstaglandinsCimetidineCCKBreceptorH2receptorGsIP3/Ca2+H+K+ ATPaseCAMPGastricparietal cellLumenOmeprazoleH+ secretionOMARROW

questions.question: Maximum gastric secretion occurs in which of the following phases?

options.D: Secretion is equal in all phases

questions.explanation: Maximum gastric secretion occurs in the gastric phase.

questions.question: Which of the following is responsible for increasing the HCl secretion in the gastric phase?
questions.explanation: HCl secretion in the gastric phase is increased by gastrin.Gastrin stimulates H+ secretion by interaction with cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on theparietal cell which secretes HCl.570Factors regulating H+ secretionVagusG cellsECL cellsD cellsAchM3AtropinereceptorGastrinHistamineCCKBreceptorH2receptorGeGaIP3/Ca2+H+K+ ATPaseSomatostatin ProstaglandinsCimetidineCAMPGastricparietal cellLumen> OmeprazoleH+ secretionOMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the secretion from the exocrine pancreas?
questions.explanation: Pancreatic secretion is stimulated by cholecystokinin (CCK) and Ach. It is always isotonic.It has virtually the same Na+ and K+ concentrations as in plasma. It is rich in several digestiveenzymes like amylase, trypsin, chymotrypsin, lipase, elastase, etc.

questions.question: Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of which of the followingstimulants?559
questions.explanation: Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of secretin.Secretin is secreted by the S cells of the duodenum. Its primary function is to promote thesecretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice by the ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum.This secretion is poor in enzymes.Other functions:•Augments the effects of CCK• Inhibits gastrin release•Decreases gastric acid secretion•Contraction of the pyloric sphincter• Exerts trophic effect on the pancreas

questions.question: Which among the following is the most alkaline secretion?
questions.explanation: The most alkaline secretion is Brunner's gland secretion with a pH of 8.0 - 8.9.571Brunner's gland is located in the first few centimeters of the duodenal wall. It secretes largeamounts of alkaline mucus in response to tactile stimuli on the duodenal mucosa, vagalstimulation, and GI hormones, especially secretin. It is inhibited by sympathetic stimulation.The function of the mucus secreted by Brunner's glands is to protect the duodenal wall fromdigestion by the highly acidic gastric juice emptying from the stomach.Note: The second most alkaline secretion in the GI tract is the pancreatic juice.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most potent choleretic?
questions.explanation: Bile salts (chemical choleretic) are the most potent choleretics.Any substance that increases bile secretion is called a choleretic. Bile secretion may be increasedby chemical (bile salts), hormonal (Secretin), and neural (vagal stimulation) mechanisms.Note: Cholagogues cause contraction of the gallbladder. Eg. CCK

questions.question: Primary bile acids are synthesized from
questions.explanation: Primary bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol by hepatocytes.Bile contains bile acids, bile salts, bile pigments, phospholipids, water, and electrolytes. It issecreted by the liver and concentrated in the gall bladder.Two primary bile acids (cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) are synthesized from cholesterolby hepatocytes. When these primary bile acids are secreted into the lumen of the intestine, aportion of each is converted to secondary bile acids (deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid) bybacteria.The liver conjugates primary and secondary bile acids with glycine or taurine to their respectivebile salts. Ex: Glycocholic acid, Taurodeoxycholic acid.Rate of bile secretion is 30 - 60 mL/hour (500 - 1000 mL/day).Note: Bile has no digestive enzymes.

questions.question: Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of
questions.explanation: Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of bile salts.The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine(terminal ileum) and the liver by means of the portal vein. It occurs 6-8 times a day.The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts.572Returned to liverVia PortalSystemSalts of HepaticOrigin95% of Bile saltsreabsorbed from Terminal IllumEnterohepatic circulation of Bile saltslts from Bacterialction in ColonFrank Boumphrey MD 2009

questions.question: Which of the following does not belong to the secretin family?
questions.explanation: CCK (Cholecystokinin) belongs to the gastrin family, not the secretin family.Classification of GI hormones based on structure and function:• Gastrin family - Gastrin, Cholecystokinin• Secretin family - Secretin, Glucagon, VIP, GIP• Others - Motilin, Ghrelin, Somatostatin, etc

questions.question: A patient underwent resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealedatrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of gastrin were found to be decreased. Which ofthe following is true regarding this GI hormone?
questions.explanation: Gastrin is a peptide hormone.It is secreted by the G cells of the gastric mucosa present in the antrum of the stomach, primarilyduring the gastric phase of gastric acid secretion.It causes gastric secretion at 1000-1500 mL/day. Its primary stimulus is gastric distension.Primary functions of Gastrin:• Gastric acid (HCl) secretion• Pepsin secretion•Trophic action on the gastric mucosaOther functions:•Stimulates gastric motility•Prevents gastroesophageal reflux by contraction of LES573Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), willcause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa.Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), willcause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.

questions.question: What is the effect of cholecystokinin on GIT?
questions.explanation: Cholecystokinin (CCK) inhibits gastric emptying.It is secreted by the I cells of the duodenal and jejunal mucosa in response to monoglycerides,fatty acids, and amino acids.Primary functions:• Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion• Contraction of the gallbladder• Relaxation of the sphincter of OddiOther functions:•••Augmentation of the action of secretin in producing alkaline (bicarbonate rich) pancreatic juice•Inhibition of gastric emptyingTrophic (growth) effect on the exocrine pancreas•Increases the synthesis of enterokinase••It enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon•Along with secretin, it augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter and thus preventing thereflux of duodenal contents into the stomach• It promotes satiety

questions.question: What stimulates secretin secretion?561
questions.explanation: Secretin secretion is stimulated by acid.Stimuli that increase secretin secretion:• Low duodenal pH (2-4.5) due to acid in the chyme• Products of protein digestion in the upper small intestineSecretin secretion is regulated by negative feedback:574Secretin secretionLow pHM*Secretin+HCO3 secretionNeutralization of pHOMARROWNegativefeedback

questions.question: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.explanation: Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells.Plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:• Albumin••Coagulation/clotting factorsAcute-phase proteinsSteroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.question: How much is the daily secretion of gastric juice?
questions.explanation: Daily secretion of gastric juice is between 1500-2000 mL.Note: This is a controversial question- Daily secretion of gastric juice is• 1500 mL according to Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th edition, Page no:819• 2500 mL according to Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology - 25th Edition, Page no:464Choose 2500 mL if given in the options. If not, choose within the range of 1500-2500 mL.

questions.question: Which of the following statement is correct regarding secretin?
questions.explanation: Secretin increases HCO3- secretion by ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum.It is secreted by the S cells in the upper small intestine.575Functions of secretion are:•Primary function• ↑ HCO3- secretion by ductal cells of pancreas and duodenum• Other functions•Augments the effects of CCK•Inhibits gastrin release↓ gastric acid secretion•Contraction of pyloric sphincter• Exerts trophic effect on the pancreas

questions.question: Which of the following is secreted by the I cells of duodenum?
questions.explanation: I cells of the duodenum secrete CCK.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presented with abdominal pain and diarrhea. On investigations, multipleulcers were seen in the proximal and distal duodenum and in the jejunum. The gastric pHwas found to be 1.2 with a serum gastrin concentration of 2000 pg/ml. Which of the followingis the primary site for the production of GI hormone raised in this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. In this condition, serumgastrin concentration is raised to around >1000 pg/ml. Gastrin is primarily secreted by G cellspresent in the antrum of the stomach.

questions.question: Which of the following hormones do not act on the pancreas?
questions.explanation: Gastrin does not act upon the pancreas. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastricmucosal growth.GI hormones acting on the pancreas include:GIP is also known as Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide.CCK(Cholecystokinin)Stimulat Pancreatic enzyme secretionesInhibitsPancreatic bicarbonate secretionGallbladder contractionGrowth of exocrine pancreasGastric emptyingSecretinPepsin secretion Pancreatic bicarbonate secretionBiliary bicarbonate secretionGrowth ofexocrine pancreasGastric acid secretionGIP (Gastric inhibitory peptide)Insulin releaseGastric acid secretion576
